columns.text: In this exercise, we have to determine the current share price of the stock and homemade dividend.
**Homemade Dividend** is the amount of dividend per share that an investors determines to fulfill his objectives of cash-flow.

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem.

| |Amounts | 
|--|--:| 
| Dividend Price|$ 3.15 | 
| Liquidating Dividend Price|57 | 
| Required Rate of Return| 15%|

To begin, let's us calculate the current share price of the stock by adding the first and second year present value of dividend. The current share price of the stock is computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Current Share Price} 
 &=\dfrac{\text{DP}}{\text{(1 + r)}} + \dfrac{\text{LDP}}{\text{$(1 + r)^2$}} \\[5pt]
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

DP - Dividend Price

LDP - Liquidating Dividend Price

r -  Required Rate of Return

Next, if the company would rather have equal dividends in each of the next two years, we can accomplish this by creating a homemade dividends. To begin, let's first share price in year 1 by dividing the liquidating dividend price by the required rate of return.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Share Price in Year 1} &= \dfrac{\text{LDP}}{\text{(1 + r)}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 57}}{\text{(1 + 0.15)}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 57}}{\text{1.15}}\\[10pt]
&= \boxed{\text{\$ 49.57}}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the share price in year 1 is $49.57.

Next, we will compute the current investment by multiplying the share price to the number shares owned.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Current Investment} &= \text{Share Price}\times{\text{No. of Shares Owned}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{\$\hspace{5pt}45.84}\times{\text{1,000}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\$\hspace{5pt}45,840}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Then, we can now compute the cash flow. Note: it is mentioned in the problem that the dividend will be in the form of annuity. **Annuity** is a series of payments made at equal intervals. The cash flow is computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PMT} &= \dfrac{\text{PV}}{\dfrac{1-{\dfrac{1}{\text{$(1+i)^n$}}}}{i}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

PMT = Cash Flow

PV - Present Value

i - Required Rate of Return

n - no. of periods

Now, we can compute the cash flow using the equation in step 8.


$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PMT} &= \dfrac{\text{PV}}{\dfrac{1-{\dfrac{1}{\text{$(1+i)^n$}}}}{i}}\\[35pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{45,840}}{\dfrac{1-{\dfrac{1}{\text{$(1+0.15)^2$}}}}{0.15}}\\[35pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{45,840}}{\dfrac{1-{\dfrac{1}{\text{$(1.15)^2$}}}}{0.15}}\\[35pt]
&=\boxed{\$\hspace{5pt}28,196.93}\\
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen, the cash flow is **$ 28,196.93.**

Lastly, we will compute the number shares sold. It is computed as follows:


$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{No. of Share Sold} &= \dfrac{\text{CF}-\text{(Years $\times$ Shares Owned)}}{\text{Share Price in Year 1}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

CF - Cash Flow

Applying the formula of the number of share sold:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{No. of Share Sold} &= \dfrac{\text{CF}-\text{(Years $\times$ Shares Owned)}}{\text{Share Price in Year 1}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 28,196.93}-(\text{\text{2} $\times$ {\text{1,000)}}}}{\text{\$49.57}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 28,196.93}-{\text{2,000.00}}}{\text{\$49.57}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$ 26,196.93}}{\text{\$49.57}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{528.48 shares }}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the number of shares sold by the company in creating a homemade dividend is **528.48 shares.**
